Molybdenum disulfide /reduced Graphene Oxide /Polyaniline nanocomposites (NCs) was prepared via a two-step synthesis procedures involving hydrothermal and in-situ chemical polymerization techniques. The morphological analysis revealed a well-interconnected structure. X-ray diffraction and Raman spectroscopy revealed the effective formation of the nanocomposites, while Ultraviolet-diffuse reflectance spectroscopy demonstrated enhanced visible light absorption. The degradation rates were up to 96.59% for Methylene Blue, 70.24% for Rhodamine Blue, and 46.03% for Methyl Orange under sunlight light irradiation. The antimicrobial activity of the NCs against various strains, including Escherichia coli, Candida Albicans, and Staphylococcus aureus showed that the prepared nanocomposite possesses better effectiveness against Candida Albicans. Graphical abstract Unlabelled Image Keywords Water purification Antimicrobial treatments Photocatalytic activity MoS2 /rGO @PANI Ternary Photocatalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Over the past few decades, there has been a significant increase in the demand and development of the industrial sector to meet human needs. However, the discharge of waste products from these industries into freshwater resources has had a severe impact on the environment. One major concern is the presence of harmful dyes, which are generated as waste from various industries such as garment, textile, pharmaceuticals, etc. [1–5]. These dyes are highly stable and resistant to biodegradation, making them difficult to degrade in water. These dyes not only endanger human health by creating cancer-causing, mutagenic, and genetically harmful problems, but they also harm aquatic life. The existence of these colours in water reduces sunlight penetration, affecting photosynthesis and the aquatic ecology as an entire system. Certain synthetic dyes, including methylene blue (MB), rhodamine B (RhB), and methyl orange (MO), have been linked to diseases such as skin problems, infections of the respiratory system, and eye irritation. Therefore, it is critical to eliminate and decolorize these dyes from water bodies, as their presence can disrupt the aquatic flora and fauna [6]. In general, there are three major various types of dye removal procedures: chemical, physical, and biological. Physical methods involve adsorption, ion exchange, filtration, and coagulation, while chemical approaches include ozonization, photocatalytic reactions, and the use of Fenton's reagent. Biological methods encompass aerobic and anaerobic degradation, as well as biosorption [7–9]. Among these technologies, photocatalysis of dyes has various advantages, particularly the use of an affordable reactor, no chance of secondary pollution caused by organic component breakdown, and the capacity to be reprocessed in an environmentally acceptable manner. Various semiconductors, including oxides and sulfides, such as TiO2, SnO2, Fe2O3, ZnS, and MoS2, as well as their mixed binary and ternary forms, have been extensively studied for the photodegradation of organic pollutants like antibiotics and dyes [10–13]. Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2-MS) is a two-dimensional material consisting of a molybdenum layer nestled between two layers of sulfur, with these layers being effectively linked by the relatively weak van der Waals force. Due to its favorable chemically stable, friendly to the environment, outstanding lubricity, and adequate bandgap (around 1.9 eV), MoS2 is considered a promising photocatalyst that can harness UV–Visible light [14–17]. However, its catalytic activity is impeded by the rapid recombination of light-induced hole pairs and the limited utilization of visible light. To overcome these limitations, researchers have explored the creation of MoS2-based heterojunctions, which effectively enhance charge separation and transfer, thereby improving photocatalytic performance [18,19]. To increase the photocatalytic efficiency and stability of MoS2, various structural modifications have been investigated. These modifications include creating oxygen vacancies, incorporating other metals, doping with metals, and combining with carbonaceous materials. Notably, the combination of MoS2 with carbonaceous materials like graphene oxide, graphite, and carbon nanotubes has shown significant improvements in stability and photocatalytic activity. This is primarily attributed to the reduction in the recombination of photoexcited electrons and positive holes, as well as the enhanced adsorption capacity. Hence, the integration of reduced graphene oxide (rGO), a highly conductive carbonaceous material, with MoS2 photocatalysts increases the surface area and absorption capacity, facilitating efficient electron transport. This combination lowers the bandgap energy, increases sunlight absorption, stabilizes the composite material, and allows for effective electron-hole pair separation at the heterojunction [20,21]. However, challenges persist, such as the tendency for aggregation, difficulty in separation and recovery, and high aggregation tendency in the MoS2-rGO conjugation. To overcome these limitations, researchers have explored the use of support agents like activated carbon and conjugated polymers. One noteworthy conjugated polymer is polyaniline (PANI), which exhibits p-type characteristics and exceptional hole transport capability. PANI also demonstrates fast photogenerated charge separation, a suppress photocharge recombination rate, and excellent stability. Incorporating PANI act as effective hole transfer material on the MoS2 surface promotes improved photocatalytic performance and stability. Previous studies have highlighted the potential of PANI/rGO/MoS2 NCs in supercapacitors and lithium-ion batteries [22,23]. Previously, Hua Lv et al. [24] prepared BiPO4 NPs over the MoS2/Gr hybrid via a simple microwave-assisted hydrothermal method. BiPO4-MoS2/Gr NCs showed better catalytic activity than the bare ones. The enhanced dye removal activity through the presence of MoS2/Gr layered hybrid provides effective reactive sites for the reaction. GO/g-C3N4/MoS2 NCs were synthesized by the effective single step hydrothermal method. The flower-like heterostructure showed better photocatalytic activity, due to the effective collection of e− in MoS2, holes in g-C3N4, and effective holes transportation through GO which are beneficial for the enhanced activity, reported by Ming-hong Wu et al. [25]. Tansir Ahamad et al. [26] studied g-C3N4/ MoS2/PANI for the degradation of bisphenol-A. The authors concluded that the effective catalytic behavior of g-C3N4/ MoS2/PANI is due to the good structural morphology, good conducting, and surface states of PANI. Furthermore, its characteristics have clearly confirmed that it is able to act as a good photocatalyst for pollutant degradation in water resources. Hence, our study introduces a novel ternary photocatalyst, Molybdenum disulfide /reduced Graphene Oxide /Ployaniline (MoS2 /rGO @PANI), synthesized through a two-step process involving hydrothermal and in-situ chemical polymerization methods, followed by the photocatalyst was practically utilized to degrade diverse dye pollutants (such as Methylene Blue, Rhodamine B, and Methyl Orange) under visible light and examine antimicrobial properties (E-coli, S-aureus, and C-albicans). Additionally, we delved into the impact of scavengers and conducted kinetic analysis to understand the photocatalytic degradation mechanism. Notably, our survey of existing literature highlighted the lack of prior research on the application of MoS2/rGO @PANI nanocomposites for both dye removal and antimicrobial activity. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of MoS2/rGO (MS/rG) hybrid To synthesize the MoS2/rGO (MS/rG) hybrid, 40 mg of the prepared GO was well dispersed using ultrasonicator in 40 mL of deionized (DI) water to get a brown color GO Solution A. The graphene oxide used in this study was successfully prepared using a modified Hummers method, as described in the report [27]. Secondly, in a separate beaker, 0.182 g of sodium molybdate (Na2MoO4·2H2O) and 0.211 g of thiourea (CH4N2S) were dispersed in 20 mL of deionized water, forming Solution B. Then, Solution B was then added to Solution A, kept ultrasonicating for 30 mins. Finally, the resultant sonicate solution was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, strongly sealed, and heated at 200 °C for 24 h [26]. The product was collected and cleaned one time with ethanol and three times with deionized water, once the autoclave reached room temperature. Subsequently, the products were dried at 80 °C overnight [21], resulting in the synthesis of the MoS2/rGO nanocomposite, designated as MS/rG. The same process was used to prepare pure MoS2 (MS), but without the inclusion of GO. 2.2 Synthesis of ternary nanocomposite (MS/rG @P) The synthesis and the ratio of precursor used to prepare the MS/rG @P ternary NCs as per literature reports [28–31]. Initially, 20 mL of 0.1 M HCl was added to 40 mL of deionized water. Subsequently, 1.14 mL of aniline (C6H5NH2) and 125 mg of MoS2/rGO NCs were introduced into the acidic solution. Another solution of 0.1 M APS ((NH4)2S2O8) in 50 mL DI water was prepared separately. A homogeneous solution was prepared by mixing 13 mL of the as prepared APS oxidant solution with the aniline monomer and MoS2/rGO NCs acid solution. The in-situ polymerization was carried out in an ice bath (0–4 °C) for 4 h. The solution's color transitioned from dark black to dark green, signifying the formation of MS/rG @P NCs. Following several washes with ethanol and the deionized water, the resulting product obtained was greenish-black MS/rG @P NCs. The obtained product was coded as MS/rG @P NCs. The schematic of the MS/rG @P NCs preparation is shown in Fig. 1 . 2.3 Characterization The structural, chemical, optical, and electrical properties of the synthesized samples were analyzed using a number of characterization techniques. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) was conducted using the Zeiss SUPRA25 instrument to obtain high-resolution images. For transmittance electron microscopy (TEM), the HRTEM JEM 2011 was utilized, providing detailed results. Crystallographic information was obtained through X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis, enabling the determination of the sample's crystal structure. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) characterization was performed using the JASCO FT/IR-4600 instrument to examine the sample's chemical bonds and functional groups. Raman spectroscopy was employed for hybrid junction examinations, allowing for the analysis of the sample's electronic and vibrational properties. Ultra Violet-diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV-DRS) using the JASCO V-770 instrument was utilized to investigate the optical properties of the samples. Photoluminescence (PL) properties of the prepared NCs were recorded using the JASCO FP-8300 spectrofluorometer. Experimental conditions for antimicrobial and photocatalytic activity were provided in the supplementary section, while the percentage of degradation efficiency was calculated using a previously reported equation [32,33]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphological microstructure properties in MS/rG @P NCs for the degradation of pollutants Pure MS, MS/rG, and MS/rG @P NCs were characterized using FESEM, to know about microstructure and morphological properties. Fig. 2 (a) illustrates the pristine MS shows the nano calendula flower-like stack structure and highly visible edges sites. When an appropriate amount of GO was added to the MoS2 precursor solution, the nano petals like aggregate MoS2 were evenly distributed over the surface of GO. The morphological image of chemically prepared GO was portrayed in Fig. S1. The gapless well-interconnected interaction between MoS2 and GO is due to the surface of GO containing an enormous amount of oxygenated functional groups such as hydroxyl, epoxy, carbonyl, and defects sites [21] (Fig. 2 (b) & S2 (a) & (b)). In ternary nanocomposite (Fig. 2 (c)), the stack visible active edge layer MoS2/rGO is fully covered by PANI, and its looks like a fluffy morphology with an interconnected structure. This is due to the benzenoid and quinoid groups present on the PANI is greatly attached with the functional groups present in the MoS2/rGO. So, it will enhance the conductivity of MS/rG nanocomposite via transferring electrons from the MoS2/rGO to the PANI [22,23,26]. TEM in-depth morphological property of the ternary NCs were displayed in Fig. 2 (d)-(g). The binary NCs of MS/rG, the visible active sites with the d-spacing of 0.68 nm aggregated hexagonal phase MoS2 strongly anchored on the thin sheet of rGO (Fig. S1 (c)-(f)). The large interlayer spacing of the MoS2 promote the easier adsorption of dye molecules, which leads to enhancing the dye removal property [33]. After the addition of GO the aggregation of MoS2 greatly suppress, which means that the GO acts as the substrate to promote the nucleation of MoS2. Another one is interlunar d-spacing ∼0.468 nm, which might be related to the GO scarps [34]. Fig. 2 (d)-(g) MS/rG @P ternary NCs shows the Ms./rG was fully covered, well-interconnected structure. The great attachment is due to the electrostatic interaction between the positively charged PANI and negatively charged MS/rG [35,36]. But the edges of the ternary NCs exhibit the d-spacing of 0.68 nm and 0.35 nm related to the MoS2 and rGO. STEM and mapping also confirm the well-interconnected, fully covered, and even distribution of NCs (Fig. 2 (h) & (i)). The well-interconnected 3D wrinkle nanostructure of Ms./rG @P intimate contact possesses enhanced conductivity, surface area, and active sites and provides more channels for effective reaction, benefiting its catalytic performance. Also the morphological analysis exhibits that the surface of the ternary NCs is drastically changed. Especially, TEM images (200 nm) portrayed the highly active visible edges are visible and the diameter of nano calendula flower MS/rG is around 346 nm for the binary NCs, but for ternary NCs the binary NCs are fully covered with the PANI so the active sites are unclear and the diameter of the MS/rG is increased. Furthermore, similar observations were reported for MoS2-warped rGO by polyaniline when used for supercapacitor applications [37,38]. The SAED pattern depicts (Fig. S1 (g)) the diffraction rings are hazy and very weak, reflecting the MS/rG NCs is amorphous in nature (the degree of crystallization is very low). To know the distribution of each element in MS/rG, the STEM mapping characterization was carried out, and the recorded spectrum was portrayed in Fig. S1 (i). 3.2 Crystal structural, vibrational, and surface area properties of the MS/rG @P NCs photocatalyst Fig. 3 (a) depicts the XRD illustration of pure MS, MS/rG, and MS/rG @P ternary nanocomposite. For Pure MoS2, the appearance of diffraction peaks at the position of 13.90°, 32.49°, and 57.76° were attributed to (002), (100), and (110) reflections of 2H- MoS2 in good agreement with JCPDS card # 37–1492. The presence of the (002) reflection clearly shows that the prepared sample has more monolayers (number of layers) of MoS2 which are stacked together along the c-axis [39–42]. For binary MS/rG nanocomposite, the new reflection peak at 18.80° (denoted in ‘#’) with a d-spacing of 4.71 Å corresponds with TEM results. This might be due to the insertion of GO scarps into the layers of MoS2 during the hydrothermal process [34]. Compared with pure and binary NCs, all the intensity peaks were greatly reduced, and FWHM of the peak increased after the addition of PANI in the ternary nanocomposite, due to the amorphous nature of PANI. This will decrease the crystallinity of the composite. The peaks related to PANI are not clearly visible, which may be due to the very low amount of PANI in the ternary nanocomposite [35,43]. The underlying reason was explored in the following characterization techniques. To demonstrate the functional group of the ternary NCs, an FTIR study was examined from the wavenumber of 400–4000 cm−1 (Fig. 3 (b)). All three samples show the same transmittance peaks at different positions such as 3425, 3110, 1622, 1397, 1135, 925, 604, and 554 cm−1. In 3425 and 1622 cm−1, the OH stretching vibration mode peak was noticed. The absorption peak at 3110 cm−1 is attributed to the vibration stretching mode of CH. The SO asymmetric stretching vibration peak was seen at wavenumber position of 1135 cm−1. The peaks 925, 604, and 554 cm−1 are due to the MoS2 two different modes of stretching's (MoO and MoS) [44,45]. In the MS/rG and MS/rG @P composite spectrum, one additional peak at 1600 cm−1 confirms the rGO (CC stretching vibration) was successfully integrated with the MS [46]. Ternary nanocomposite depicts a less intense absorption peak compared to MS, and MS/rG, along with the extra peaks at 1484 and 800 cm−1 is CC stretching vibration mode of benzenoid and quinoid rings, as well as CH out of plane bending in the benzene ring, has been ascribed [47]. The pure MS, MS/rG, and MS/rG @P samples were also examined by Raman spectroscopy, in order to prove the successful incorporation of GO and PANI in the ternary NCs. The characteristic peak corresponding to the 2D MoS2 and rGO, portrayed in Fig. 3 (c). The Raman spectra of all three samples revealed five unique peaks at 237, 283, 335, 375, and ∼ 402 cm−1 due to the active mode of 2H-MoS2 (Fig. 3 (d)) which are well-matched with the previously reported data [48–50]. The main peak detected at ∼402, 375, and 283 cm−1 is ascribed to the first-order active mode of A1g, E12g, and E1g of 2H-MoS2 [48,51]. E12g and A1g vibration modes are assigned to in-plane and out-of-plane vibration of S-Mo-S layers. For pure MoS2, the vibration modes of the E12g and A1g are found at the position of 375 and 405 cm−1. The space between E12g and A1g Raman modes could decrease as the number of MoS2 layers decreases. In pure MoS2 the distance between the two peaks is 30 cm−1 suggesting that the prepared MoS2 is in bulk form (number of layers) [15,52], consistent with the result of XRD. The predominant peaks noticed at 800–1000 cm−1 are caused by the molecular structure of Mo3S13, which is placed at the edges of MoS2. This demonstrates the presence of numerous unsaturated MoS edge sites [49]. In addition, the other two peaks at 1361 cm−1 (D-band) and 1580 cm−1 (G-band) in MS/rG, and MS/rG @P are due to the incorporation of GO into the nanocomposite. The D-band and G-band are due to the defect sites and the vibration of the SP2-bonded carbon atom [53,54]. In ternary nanocomposite, MS/rG @P the intensity of all the peaks is greatly suppressed due to the addition of PANI. The Raman peaks related to PANI will not detectable due to the high-intensity peaks of rGO and the 2D-MoS2. In addition, the intensity of the peaks E12g and A1g gives some useful information about the MoS2 surface and edge-terminated terrace structure. If the intensity ratio of the peaks is higher, represents the prepared samples are surface-terminated terrace structures. The intensity of peaks is lower related to the edge terminated structure and also this structure configuration is unstable [51]. Based on the aforementioned statement the prepared MS/rG @P sample exhibits more exposed edge active sites due to its lower intensity ratio of E12g and A1g. Because of the more visible active sites of MS/rG @P, the dye molecules will strongly interact with the sample's edge sites through an unstable dangling bond. Overall, the obtained structural and vibration characteristics of the synthesized MS/rG @P nanocomposite will be more influential factors in enhancing the photocatalytic performance compared to pristine MS, and MS/rG. Meanwhile, the surface area and the porosity of the prepared NCs was determined by using N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms. Brunauer- Emmet-Teller (BET) process is used to measure the surface area. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of MS, MS/rG, and MS/rG @P have been shown in Fig. 4 (a). The BET specific surface area of MS, MS/rG and MS/rG @P were determined to be 5.61 m2/g, 18.14 m2/g, and 12.6m2/g, respectively. The bare samples exhibit very low specific surface area, whereas the binary NCs shows enhanced surface area due to the addition of GO, also higher surface area reduce the aggregation of the NCs. The higher surface area gives more active sites for the dye removal reaction, which is beneficial for the dye degradation reaction [55,56]. The surface area reduced to 18.14 m2/g to 12.6 m2/g in ternary, this may be due to the PANI gets covered fully over the surface of the binary NCs. The Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) pore-size distribution graph (Fig. 4 (b)), shows the smallest narrow pore diameter of 4.2 nm for the MS sample, MS/rG binary NCs exhibits very small pore size ranging from 2 to 4 nm and 4 to 6 nm for ternary NCs. 3.3 The enhanced dye removal activity due to the higher visible light absorption and effective suppression of photogenerated charge carriers Fig. S3 presents the UV-DRS spectrum of MS, MS/rG, and MS/rG @P NCs, all the samples demonstrate the different peaks at UV as well as the visible region. Especially the MS depicts the reflectance at the wavelength of 407, 484, and 588 nm related to the various excitonic transition at the K-point (Brillouin zone) and M-point (valence and conduction band transition at the Deep level) [51]. At the same time, the other two NCs show a high-intensity peak at the whole wavelength region due to the intrinsic light absorption property of rGO and PANI. The optical energy gap of the prepared NCs were confirmed by K-M function also known as Kubelka-munk relation, the energy bandgap graph was plotted [F(R)hυ]2 versus energy (hυ). Kubelka-munk relation: F R hν 2 = 1 − R 2 / 2 R ∗ hν 2 The calculated energy gap (Eg) values are portrayed in Fig. 5 (a). Ternary NCs illustrate the reduced bandgap after the addition of rGO and PANI, so we expect the ternary NCs to deliver better catalytic activity than the bare and binary ones. The PL spectrum of the pristine MS, MS/rG, and MS/rG @P NCs are presented in Fig. 5 (b). Bare and NCs exhibit an intense emission peak at around 385 and 681 nm with an excitation wavelength of 340 nm (3.6 eV). The 385 nm emission peak emerges from the Brillouin zone's K point in the MoS2 nanosheet. At the same time, the 681 nm peak has attributed the band to band transition or intrinsic emission in MoS2 nanosheets. The binary and ternary samples had the same PL spectra as pure MoS2, but their addition of rGO and PANI increased their PL intensity, and the peaks will lightly red-shifted to 684 and 682 nm in MS/rG, and MS/rG @P NCs. 3.4 Enhanced antimicrobial activity and mechanism of the MS/rG @P NCs In Fig. 6 , the antibacterial and antifungal activity of bare MoS2, hybrid MS/rG and ternary NCs of MS/rG @P are presented. The ternary MS/rG @P exhibits maximum zone of inhibition compared to bare MS NPs and binary MS/rG NCs. Table 1 depicts the antimicrobial activities of the prepared samples. From the table, samples didn't show effective antibacterial activity whereas all the NCs exhibited good antifungal activity against the Candida albicans isolate. Among the NCs used in the study, the MS/rG @P NCs showed better antifungal activity compared to the MS and MS/rG NCs. This is due to the synergistic 2D effect of MoS2, rGO and the highly conducting nature of PANI and their structural stability emerge as an effective antifungal agent [57–59]. Reactive oxygen species is one of the self-regulating components of the microbial community as they are utilized in intercellular mechanisms such as the alteration of DNA. ROS is required to maintain cellular redox homeostasis. The increase in ROS can disrupt redox homeostasis and eventually leads to cell necrosis, particularly the ROS are capable of disrupting the cell wall, the signalling pathways of the fungi, the ion exchange channels of the fungal cell wall which are capable of disrupting entire metabolisms of fungi [60]. The rGO have been studied for their antimicrobial abilities and their anti-fouling applications. The antimicrobial activity of rGO is considerably less in the low concentration and only on the higher concentration such as 400 μg/mL [61–63]. The rGO flakes are known to have sharp edges which are responsible to damage the cell wall of the microbial cells causing the cytoplasm to leak out and lead to cell death. The rGO is also capable of increasing the oxidative stress of the microbial cells and eventually leading to cell necrosis, there are numerous studies reporting the antifungal properties of the MoS2, yet the previous researches have shown in comparison to bare MoS2 nanoparticles the antifungal activity of and of MoS2 NCs or doping with nitrogen atoms showed accelerated antifungal activity. Similarly in our study the bare in comparison with bare MS, MS/rG, and MS/rG @P NCs have shown enhanced antifungal properties [64]. 3.5 Mechanism insight for intensifying catalytic performance over the MS/rG @P photocatalyst The MB dye adsorption and photocatalytic activity of three samples (MS, MS/rG, and MS/rG @P) were shown in Fig. 7 . From Fig. 7 (a) & (b) we noticed all three samples showed better adsorption behavior towards MB dye. The adsorption experiment was initially conducted in dark conditions for 15 min. It was observed that the absorbance value obtained after 15 min was almost identical to that at 10 min. Consequently, we concluded the dark reaction after a 10-min run. The adsorption capacity of MS, MS/rG, and MS/rG @P in the order of MS/rG @P > MS/rG > MS (44.6% > 40.86% > 36.73%). The higher adsorption ability of MS/rG @P is due to the three-dimensional structure having high active edge sites and also the many absorbed organic sites of the sample. After 10 mins dark stirred condition, the photocatalytic degradation will be increased to 96.59% for MS/rG @P, 85.29% for MS/rG, and 81.48% for MS. The higher photocatalytic degradation of MS/rG @P might be due to the efficiently increased lifetime of the excited electrons at the interface and effective utilization of sunlight by the ternary nanocomposite than the other two samples MS and MS/rG. The addition of GO and PANI will enhance the surface area of the sample which will provide more active sites for the reaction and also an effective separation of charged carriers through higher electron mobility nature. Fig. 7 (c) – (e) shows the photocatalytic and adsorption behavior of MS/rG @P against different dyes (MB, RhB, MO). The prepared samples show effective adsorption behavior towards cationic dyes MB (44.6%) and RhB (42.27%), while the anionic dye MO exhibits low adsorption capacity (16.08%). The photocatalytic capacity increased from 44.6 to 96.59% for MB dye, 42.27 to 72% for RhB dye, and 16.08% to 46.03% for MO dye. This can be ascribed to the prepared ternary nanocomposite exhibiting good electrostatic interaction with the cationic dyes (MB and RhB) compared to anionic dye (MO). Table 2 presented the degradation efficiency for various dyes was compared to earlier works with different NC compositions. The stability of the MS/rG @P was tested against the MB dye for 5 consecutive cycles. Fig. 7 (f) presents the reusability cycles graph for the MS/rG @P nanocomposite. The efficiency of the nanocomposite decreased from 96.49% to 90.36% after 5 cycles, the small decrement in the efficiency is due to the catalyst loss during the centrifugation process or the dye molecules being absorbed by the voids of the NCs, which will greatly reduce the adsorption property. After performing the cyclic test, the sample was examined using different techniques to know its structural and morphological changes during the catalytic test, shown in Fig. 9. 3.5.1 Mechanism The proposed mechanism for the photodegradation of dyes using MS/rG @P heterojunction NCs is presented in Fig. 8 . Notably, the energy levels of PANI's HOMO and LUMO bands bear a close resemblance to the CB and VB of MoS2, implying a potential cooperative effect. When MS/rG @P NCs absorb sunlight, electron-hole pairs emerge. Electrons in MoS2's VB are elevated to the CB, while photo-induced holes persist in MoS2's VB. A significant feature is the ability of holes in MoS2's VB to directly transfer to PANI's HOMO due to a favorable energy level match and ensuing chemical bond interaction [74]. Consequently, PANI serves as an effective hole-transporting material [75,76], facilitating facile hole transfer to the surface and leading to the direct oxidation of adsorbed contaminants. Furthermore, the strategic integration of rGO at the MoS2 interface introduces an intriguing dynamic—formation of a Schottky barrier. This integration capitalizes on MoS2's n-type semiconductor characteristics, enhancing the ease with which photo-generated electrons residing in MoS2's CB smoothly transit through graphene. These electrons react with dissolved oxygen molecules to generate superoxide radicals that subsequently oxidize dye molecules. Moreover, oxygen-bearing functional groups within rGO, such as hydroxyl, carboxyl, carbonyl, and epoxide, undergo reduction by photogenerated electrons. Additionally, active holes remaining on PANI's LUMO readily induce the oxidation of H2O into hydroxyl, contributing to the oxidation of dye molecules. Consequently, a prompt separation of photogenerated charges, coupled with a controlled charge recombination rate, is achieved. This intricate interplay significantly amplifies the photocatalytic activity of the MS/rG @P photocatalysts. The reactions involved in degrading dye molecules using MS/rG @P are outlined below; (1) MS / rG @ P catalyst + h ν → e − CB + h + VB (2) e − CB + O 2 → • O 2 − (3) • O 2 − + 2H 2 O → 2 • OH + 2OH − (4) h + VB + 2H 2 O → • OH + H + (5) OH − + H + → • OH (6) • O 2 − + dye molecules → intermediate products + H 2 O + CO 2 (7) • OH + dye molecules → intermediate products + H 2 O + CO 2 3.6 Characterization of MS/rG @P NCs after photocatalytic degradation In addition, the crystal, molecular, and morphological stability of the ternary NCs were examined by three different instrumentation techniques such as XRD, FTIR, and FESEM after five cycle runs (Fig. 9 ). XRD presented in Fig. 9 (a), showed no peak shift in the position. But the XRD peak for reused catalysts was found to be decreased, possibly indicating that the repeated cycling process caused a reduction in the crystalline phase of the compound. Furthermore, the repeated interactions between reactants/intermediates have resulted in some defects and distortion in its crystal lattice [77], indicating that the crystallinity of the NCs slightly affected during the experiment. As discussed in the FTIR section above, the MS/rG @P ternary NCs have various functional groups at different positions based on the stretching modes of each material MoS2, rGO, and PANI. FTIR analysis Fig. 9 (b) demonstrates that the functional groups are intact even after the photocatalytic test. The only difference is transmittance intensity, this might be due to the presence of water molecules between the layers of MoS2 and the PANI surface (high adsorption property). The major peaks corresponding to the M-O and SO stretching at the lower wavenumber region do not vary. At the same time other is some extra are noticed after the catalytic tested sample, which comes from the dye molecules (absorbed dye molecules present on the sample surface). This result shows the prepared ternary NCs have better molecular stability. After 5 cycles of run, the morphological structure also does not vary, the edges are visible, and the little agglomeration. This is due to the high amount of dye absorption that occurs during the cyclic stability test Fig. 9 (c). 4 Conclusion In conclusion, this research work successfully developed and characterized a novel photocatalyst, MS/rG @P for the elimination of harmful dyes. The structural, chemical, and morphological properties of the prepared nanocomposite were thoroughly investigated using various instrumentation techniques, including XRD, FTIR, FESEM, UV-DRS, and photodegradation studies. Through XRD analysis, it was clearly confirmed that the synthesized nanocomposite possesses a crystalline nature, with diffraction peaks corresponding to the characteristic planes of MoS2. Furthermore, the inclusion of rGO and PANI did not significantly affect the crystal structure of MoS2. FTIR analysis also revealed the presence of functional groups associated with MoS2, rGO, and PANI, indicating successful synthesis and composite formation. FESEM images provided insights into the morphological properties of the prepared nanocomposite, exhibiting a well-interconnected structure with MoS2/rGO sheets uniformly dispersed over the PANI surface. This unique structure provided efficient surface area and improved conductivity, facilitating effective charge transfer and increasing the catalytic efficiency of the nanocomposite. UV-DRS spectroscopy study demonstrated that the MS/rG @P nanocomposite showed efficient visible light absorption compared to pure MoS2. The incorporation of rGO and PANI extended the absorption range, enabling the nanocomposite to harness a broader spectrum of light for photocatalytic reactions. The band gap of the nanocomposite was calculated to be 1.48 eV, indicating its ability to utilize visible light for photocatalysis. The dye removal activity of the MS/rG @P nanocomposite was practically examined through the degradation of various dye pollutants, including two cationic (MB and RhB), and one anionic (MO) dyes. The nanocomposite exhibited excellent photocatalytic degradation efficiency, with a degradation rate of 96.59% for MB, 70.24% for RhB, and 46.03% for MO within a short period. This high photocatalytic efficiency can be attributed to the synergistic effects of MoS2, rGO, and PANI, which enhanced the separation and transfer of photogenerated charge carriers, promoting the efficient degradation of the dyes. Furthermore, the MS/rG @P nanocomposite exhibited promising antimicrobial activity against Candida albicans, a common fungal pathogen. The presence of MoS2 and rGO in the nanocomposite contributed to its antifungal properties, effectively inhibiting fungal growth. Overall, these research findings contribute to the development of advanced materials for environmental remediation and water treatment applications, emphasizing the importance of integrating NCs with enhanced properties for sustainable and efficient pollutant removal. coredata.dc:description: Molybdenum disulfide /reduced Graphene Oxide /Polyaniline nanocomposites (NCs) was prepared via a two-step synthesis procedures involving hydrothermal and in-situ chemical polymerization techniques. The morphological analysis revealed a well-interconnected structure. X-ray diffraction and Raman spectroscopy revealed the effective formation of the nanocomposites, while Ultraviolet-diffuse reflectance spectroscopy demonstrated enhanced visible light absorption. The degradation rates were up to 96.59% for Methylene Blue, 70.24% for Rhodamine Blue, and 46.03% for Methyl Orange under sunlight light irradiation. The antimicrobial activity of the NCs against various strains, including Escherichia coli, Candida Albicans, and Staphylococcus aureus showed that the prepared nanocomposite possesses better effectiveness against Candida Albicans.

coredata.dc:title: Emerging robust heterostructure of flower-like (Calendula) MoS2-warped rGO by polyaniline nanohybrid for antimicrobial and antipollution performances
